I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In its new socioeconomic development plan, 2011–2015 the Government of Viet Nam 
recognizes regional cooperation and integration (RCI) as an important policy area in Viet Nam’s 
further development. RCI is identified as one of the five core operational areas in the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2020,1 which commits to increasing public and private sector 
operations at the regional and subregional levels to at least 30% of its total activities by 2020. 
ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 for Viet Nam also considers RCI as one of its 
priority  thematic  issues.2 Hence,  the  government  strongly  requested  ADB  to  continue  its 
assistance  in  strengthening  Viet  Nam’s  capacity  to  deal  with  RCI  issues,  particularly  in 
investment planning for RCI projects and programs so that Viet Nam can further benefit from 
and  contribute  to  RCI  initiatives.  The  scope,  expected  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  and 
implementation arrangements were discussed and finalized during the technical assistance (TA) 
fact-finding mission conducted on 5–19 April 2012. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  In Viet Nam, the coordination of RCI initiatives is particularly complex because of the 
large number of RCI initiatives involved,4 and the different dimensions of coordination required 
for each of them.5 There is no single agency supervising all RCI initiatives, and the Ministry of 
Planning and Investment (MPI) and Ministry of Foreign Affairs are mandated to serve as the 
national focal points for different RCI initiatives; RCI coordination is fragmented between the two 
ministries. There is no formal and functioning mechanism that looks at the totality of Viet Nam’s 
participation across these initiatives, sets a strategic direction to effectively position Viet Nam in 
different regional groupings, and determines national priorities across the initiatives to avoid 
overlap. Also, no standard operational procedures are in place for RCI coordination. The MPI is 
the lead agency in coordinating the planning of public investments, including those for RCI 
activities.  However,  national  and  subnational  governments  lack  an  effective  coordination 
mechanism and staff capacity and knowledge of RCI planning, and this weakens investment 
efficiency. 
 
3.  There is also no solid coordination mechanism between central and provincial authorities. 
Central ministries provide budget and directives to their respective provincial units, which will 
then report on the progress of their tasks to the central ministries. Although informed on key 
activities, the provincial people’s committees and units associated with other central ministries 
may not always be involved in this decision-making and reporting process. This mechanism 
does not encourage active interaction between local authorities and provincial units of central 
ministries, which increases the risk of isolating policy decisions from the reality on the ground.

4  Initiatives include (i) Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)–Mekong Basin Development Cooperation, 
(ii)  Cambodia–Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic–Myanmar–Viet  Nam  Cooperation,  (iii)  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion (GMS), (iv) West–East Corridor, (v) Triangle Development, (vi) Two Corridors One Belt, (vii) ASEAN, 
(viii) ASEAN+3 and ASEAN+1, (ix) Ayeyawady–Chao Phraya–Mekong Economic Cooperation Strategy, (x) East–
West  Economic  Corridor,  (xi)  Asia–Pacific  Economic  Cooperation,  and  (xii)  the  Mekong  River  Commission 
Program. 
5  Includes  (i)  intraministerial  coordination  involving  different  departments  within  a  ministry,  (ii)  interministerial 
coordination among various ministries, (iii) coordination between central line ministries and provincial authorities, 
and (iv) coordination between national focal agencies and region-wide institutions.

2   
Inadequate RCI coordination within the government also affects the efficiency of Viet Nam’s 
national focal point for each of the RCI initiatives and their working relationships with their 
secretariats, such as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Secretariat based in 
Jakarta (Indonesia) and the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Secretariat in ADB headquarters 
in Manila. 
 
4.  Staff involved in planning RCI activities generally lack skills and knowledge critical for 
their responsibilities, i.e., skills for general public investment planning and specific knowledge of 
planning RCI activities. Limited capacity is particularly evident at the provincial level. Apart from 
the mismatch of skills and work requirements,  the awareness of  provincial staff of global, 
regional, and national development issues, as well as the benefit of RCI, is generally low. Poor 
coordination and information dissemination from the central to provincial agencies contributes 
greatly to the human resource capacity weaknesses at the provincial level. This has been 
inhibiting provincial staff from participating effectively in planning RCI activities. 
 
5.  The absence of an effective coordination mechanism and the lack of staff skills and 
knowledge  for  planning  RCI  activities  limit  the  possibility  of  seeking  complementarity  and 
synergy between and among RCI programs and projects. This affects the achievement of 
intended  results  and  substantial  development  impact.  If  Viet  Nam  is  to  successfully  be 
integrated into the ASEAN Economic Community (to be realized by 2015) and implement the 
GMS new Strategic Framework, 2012–2022 (approved at the Fourth GMS Summit in December 
2011), it is essential for the country to improve the efficiency of RCI coordination and investment 
planning, particularly given Viet Nam's significant demand for infrastructure improvement and 
social services. 
 
6.  ADB has helped Viet Nam strengthen its RCI coordination through the TA for Capacity 
Strengthening of Viet Nam’s Regional Coordination and Public Investment Planning6 with an 
initial set up for a standard RCI coordination mechanism and a needs assessment on capacity 
building to improve the skills of government officials to manage relevant activities. However, 
after project completion, progress in these areas stalled and the recommended coordination 
mechanism and training program were not fully adopted. There were two main reasons for this 
shortfall. First, the commitment of the MPI’s former senior management was weak, and the 
government had not provided clear guidance on RCI strategies suitable for the country’s new 
development  stage.  In  addition,  necessary  revisions  to  the  existing  institutional  and 
organizational arrangements within the government were politically difficult before the Eleventh 
National Congress of the Communist Party of Viet Nam7 was held in January 2011. Second, 
adequate  financial  and  human  resources  were  not  provided  to  institutionalize  TA 
recommendations.  The  situation  has  significantly  changed  with  the  stronger  importance 
attached  to  RCI  in  Viet  Nam’s  development  process  and  public  investment  efficiency  as 
indicated in the new socioeconomic development plan. Not only is the new MPI management 
very keen on and committed to improving RCI-related work (with the new minister, who is 
originally from a province, actively involved in and benefiting from RCI activities), it is also 
responsible for rationalizing and reprioritizing public investment plans including RCI projects. 
The government also focuses on public sector management as part of its effort to restructure 
the economy. It is strongly recognized that improved policy coordination and capacity building 
are key to the reform process in general and Viet Nam’s more productive integration into RCI

Regional Coordination and Public Investment Planning. Manila (TA 4788-VIE, approved on 11 May).

initiatives. Therefore, it is timely to provide the government with this TA to continue with its 
unfinished  agenda  for  RCI  institutional  and  capacity  strengthening  before  it  enters  a  new 
development decade of more comprehensive integration. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA aims to improve the efficiency of public investments for RCI initiatives. The TA’s 
expected  outcome  will  be  strengthened  capacity  and  coordination  for  effective  investment 
planning of RCI activities in Viet Nam. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will take a focused approach to pilot expected changes with the GMS program 
which is considered the most active RCI initiative in Viet Nam, before replicating these changes 
in other RCI initiatives. Three outputs will be produced: (i) a national coordination network for 
the GMS program, (ii) a national GMS investment framework and national GMS investment plan 
for Viet Nam, and (iii) a capacity building program on GMS investment planning. These outputs 
will help streamline and institutionalize the coordination mechanism for the GMS program, and 
provide staff involved in GMS planning with investment directions and practical knowledge, skills, 
and tools to effectively participate in planning and programming GMS activities. This experiment 
on the GMS program will provide good lessons for other RCI initiatives, which will contribute to 
strengthening the capacity for and coordination of overall RCI investment planning in Viet Nam.  
 
9.  National  coordination  network  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  program.  A 
national coordination network will be set up to promote information sharing and consultation on 
the  GMS  program  among  stakeholders.  The  network  will  comprise,  among  others, 
representatives from central agencies involved in the GMS program, provinces participating in 
the GMS corridors and projects, and the private sector. The network members are expected to 
meet on a quarterly basis and/or as needed to discuss GMS policy-related issues, review the 
implementation of the GMS program in Viet Nam, and agree on GMS annual investment plans. 
GMS network meetings will invite network members and other government officials suitable for 
selected meeting topics. Communication among network members will be promoted not only 
through network meetings but also via frequent online network exchange, as well as other 
traditional paper-based communication. 
 
10.  The  current  National  GMS  Secretariat8 will  play  the  lead  role  in  running  the  GMS 
coordination  network.  For  its  effective  function,  the  secretariat  will  be  strengthened  with 
additional  resources  provided  by  the TA  and the  MPI,  including  international  and  national 
consultants, and administrative support staff. Specifically, the secretariat will receive technical 
and administrative support to 
(i)   carry out a comprehensive review of current coordination mechanisms of key 
ongoing RCI initiatives in Viet Nam, with a quick study on experience and models 
of other countries applicable to Viet Nam to draw useful lessons for the GMS 
program’s coordination mechanism; 
                                                
8  The MPI’s Foreign Economic Relations Department was officially assigned the secretariat role of the GMS program 
in 2003, and its director general is the GMS national coordinator. The director general is mainly assisted in 
monitoring and coordinating the GMS program by two departmental staff on a part-time basis.

4   
(ii)   develop a basic database of core RCI activities for information and reference by 
network members;  
(iii)   produce monthly national GMS e-updates to provide updated information on 
GMS-related policies and activities to network members;  
(iv)   organize  regular  network  meetings  and  thematic  and/or  sector  meetings  as 
needed;  
(v)   draft appropriate and legally binding regulations on information dissemination, 
reporting, and planning of GMS activities based on operational experience of the 
network for the government’s consideration as necessary; and  
(vi)   assess the applicability of the piloted GMS network to other RCI initiatives.  
 
11.  These  assignments  will  help  the  network  function  more  effectively,  improving  the 
coordination among GMS stakeholders. Three surveys (tentatively at the TA inception, midterm 
review, and completion stages) will be conducted among network members on the performance 
of the secretariat and scope for improvement. The survey results will be used to help design, 
and  adjust  as  necessary,  the  technical  and  administrative  support  to  be  provided  to  the 
secretariat under the TA. Under the TA a set of recommendations will be prepared on the 
appropriate role and responsibilities performed by the secretariat, the resource requirements 
needed to ensure the sustainability of the secretariat function and the coordination network, and 
possible replication to other RCI programs after TA completion. 
 
12.  National Greater Mekong Subregion investment framework and national Greater 
Mekong Subregion investment plan. The national GMS investment framework and plan will 
be developed, taking in account relevant agreements made in the Regional GMS Investment 
Framework prepared in light of the GMS Strategic Framework, to make sure the Regional GMS 
Investment  Framework  is  translated  into  national  and  subnational  plans  for  actual 
implementation.  This  exercise  will  require  extensive  participation  of  a  wide  range  of 
stakeholders,  including  development  partners  and  the  private  sector,  to  mobilize  essential 
resources  for  the  regional  development  targets  by  the  completion  of  the  GMS  Strategic 
Framework, 2012–2022. Advice from major investors in Viet Nam, such as Japan and other 
GMS countries, will be useful. 
 
13.  Capacity  building  program in  regional  cooperation  and  integration  investment 
planning. The program will be tailored to meet critical needs of government officials, especially 
those at the provincial level involved in RCI work, particularly investment planning. Specific 
training courses will be determined during the TA implementation after a thorough training 
needs assessment is conducted in close consultation with agencies concerned. The courses will 
cover general coordination skills, e.g., data compilation and analysis, and report writing skills for 
junior officials; and results-based and integrated investment planning for mid-level officials. The 
capacity building program will also include thematic and/or sector policy training for government 
officials  and  other  selected  stakeholder  representatives.  This  training  will  address  specific 
issues in prioritized areas of the GMS Strategic Framework. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB, and $50,000 will be 
provided  by  the  government  to  supplement  TA  administration  and  support  costs.  The 
government will also provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff remuneration, 
provision of office space and office equipment as needed, and other in-kind contributions. Total 
government counterpart support is estimated to account for 11% of the total TA cost. The cost

5 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. ADB will ensure that TA funding is made clear 
in public communications, meetings, and events funded by the TA and by other appropriate 
means. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The MPI will be the executing agency. The National GMS Secretariat established under 
the MPI’s Department of Foreign Economic Relations will manage day-to-day activities of the 
TA  with  assistance  from  international  and  national  consultants  provided  by  the  TA.  Close 
coordination will be maintained with the Regional GMS Secretariat based in Manila. 
 
16.  The TA will require 8 person-months of international consulting services in regional 
cooperation institutional development, and 84 person-months of national consulting services in 
regional  cooperation,  economic  planning,  information  and  communication  technology,  and 
project coordination. The outline terms of references for consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
consultants will be recruited individually by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Engagement of individual consultants is 
deemed suitable for this TA as expected outputs require knowledge of and experience in 
handling a combination of multidimensional RCI matters, intragovernment coordination, and 
public investment planning, as well as a good understanding of Viet Nam and other countries in 
the GMS which participate in RCI initiatives. Technical expertise and training support provided 
through consulting services may be supplemented by engaging short-term resource persons on 
specific subjects such as effective use of external development financing or foreign direct 
investment promotion, if necessary. Office equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment will be handed 
over to the executing agency upon completion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). The executing agency will administer costs for trainings and 
workshops. An advance payment facility shall be used to receive deposits from ADB. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented from January 2013 to December 2015. The TA’s expected 
outputs and outcome will be jointly monitored and evaluated by the MPI and ADB during TA 
inception, midterm, and final review missions. TA progress reports will be made on a quarterly 
basis and discussed semiannually with the MPI and relevant government ministries. Project 
reports will be disseminated in TA workshops and on the MPI website. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Capacity Building and Coordination Improvement for Effective Regional Cooperation Investment 
Planning, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of consultants will be engaged to provide advisory and technical services for the 
technical assistance (TA). The TA will require the services of 8 person-months of international 
consultants and 84 person-months of national consultants. The general requirements for these 
consultants  will  be  (i)  relevant  technical  expertise  based  on  academic  and  professional 
experience, (ii) familiarity with regional cooperation concepts and initiatives, (iii) excellent oral 
and written communication skills, and (iv) relevant work experience in Viet Nam. 
2.  The consultants will prepare reports on their tasks, and other documents as required 
under the TA and requested by the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), the executing 
agency. The basic reports will include the following, unless otherwise specified: (i) inception 
report due within 1 month from the start of engagement, (ii) quarterly progress reports to include 
the TA implementation status and recommendations to resolve bottlenecks, and (iii) completion 
report. 
 
3.  Regional  cooperation  institutional  development  specialist  and  team  leader 
(international, 8 person-months). The team leader must have a postgraduate degree in public 
administration or a related field, relevant skills and experience with the issues to be addressed, 
and at least 5 years work experience in regional cooperation and integration (RCI) issues in the 
countries  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations.  Work  experience  in  Viet  Nam, 
including knowledge of the institutional arrangements and regional cooperation issues of the 
country, will be an advantage. The specialist will report to the MPI and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), and take lead in preparing TA key reports (i.e., inception report, progress reports, 
and completion report) and other TA-related reports at the request of the MPI and ADB, and will 
be supported by national consultants in their individual capacity assigned. The assignment 
includes the following tasks: 
(i)  Project  team  leader.  The  team  leader  will  oversee  overall  project 
implementation  and  supervise  other  consultants’  inputs  to  ensure  that  the 
project’s outputs are smoothly implemented, reports are produced on a timely 
basis, key results and lessons of the project are adequately disseminated, and 
TA budget is appropriately and effectively utilized. During the absence of the 
specialist, the team leadership role will automatically be assumed by the deputy 
team leader. 
(ii)  Assess effectiveness of the National Greater Mekong Subregion Secretariat. 
The team leader will lead a quick assessment of the effectiveness of the current 
National Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Secretariat, and recommend and 
help implement measures to ensure the National GMS Secretariat continues 
performing  its  role  and  responsibilities  in  a  sustainable  manner,  including 
preparation of an operations manual and a detailed annual work plan for the 
secretariat, for the GMS national coordinator’s concurrence. 
(iii)  Review key ongoing regional cooperation and integration initiatives. The 
team leader will lead the review of the current coordination mechanism of key 
ongoing RCI initiatives in Viet Nam, as well as a quick study on RCI experience 
and  coordination  models  of  other  countries  applicable  to  Viet  Nam,  to 
recommend good practices for the GMS program coordination mechanism. 
(iv)  Formulate  a  database  of  key  regional  cooperation  and  integration 
initiatives.  In  consultation  with  government  agencies  involved  in  planning 
regional  cooperation  activities,  the  team  leader  will  formulate  the  database 
structure, supervise the compilation of information for the database, and facilitate

Appendix 3  11 
the submission of the request for posting the database on the MPI’s official 
website. 
(v)  Draft a circular on coordination for the Greater Mekong Subregion program. 
The team leader will lead the review and drafting of appropriate regulations on 
information dissemination, reporting, and planning for GMS activities, in close 
consultation with government agencies concerned, and facilitate submission to 
the government for approval. 
(vi)  Organize Greater Mekong Subregion national network meetings. Under the 
guidance  of  the  national  GMS  coordinator  and  in  close  coordination  with 
agencies involved in the GMS program, the team leader will lead in setting up the 
network;  organizing  regular  meetings;  and  preparing  meeting  agendas, 
background papers, and proceedings, with support from national consultants. 
(vii)  Supervise  preparation  of  the  national  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
investment framework and national Greater Mekong Subregion investment 
plan.  The  team  leader  will  supervise  the  preparation  of  the  national  GMS 
investment framework (NIF) and the national GMS investment plan (NIP), under 
the direct guidance of the national GMS coordinator and in close consultation 
with agencies involved in the GMS program. 
(viii)  Capacity building. Under the direct guidance of the national GMS coordinator 
and in close consultation with agencies involved in the GMS program, the team 
leader will carry out a training needs assessment with assistance from national 
consultants, design training courses for different targeted groups of trainees, and 
identify  appropriate  resource  persons  and  coordinate  with  them  to  develop 
training materials and conduct training programs. 
 
4.  Regional  cooperation  specialist  and  deputy  team  leader  (national,  20  person-
months). The deputy team leader should have a postgraduate degree in international relations 
or a related field, extensive knowledge of regional cooperation initiatives involving Viet Nam, 
and  at  least  5  years  work  experience  in  regional  cooperation  coordination  activities.  The 
specialist should also have skills and comprehensive experience with project and/or office 
administration and demonstrated relevant experience in government institutional set ups and 
procedures, and be proficient in written and oral English. The specialist will work closely with the 
team leader and other international and national consultants to complete tasks assigned, and 
will report to the team leader, or to the MPI and ADB, on the team leader’s requests. The 
assignment includes the following tasks: 
(i)  Deputy project team leader. In the absence of the team leader, the deputy 
team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  overseeing  project  implementation  and 
ensuring that implementation of the envisaged project outcomes is on schedule. 
The deputy team leader will also help ensure the postcompletion sustainability of 
the  National  GMS  Secretariat’s  function,  coordination  mechanisms  to  be 
established and enhanced, and other related outputs. 
(ii)  Overall project administration. The deputy team leader, under direct guidance 
of the team leader and the national GMS coordinator and in close collaboration 
with the consultant team, will be responsible for the day-to-day operations of the 
project. Specifically, the deputy team leader will (a) monitor and recommend the 
use of TA budget; (b) contract out services when needed; (c) ensure the smooth 
flow  of  documents  and  communication  to  all  stakeholders  concerned;  (d) 
coordinate the operationalization of the key project outputs; (e) schedule project 
activities;  (f)  collect  and  compile  basic  project  information;  and  (g)  assist  in 
preparing project inception, progress, and completion reports, and other project-
related reports upon request.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iii)  General  inputs  to  project  activities.  As  the  project  involves  a  number  of 
ministries and agencies, the deputy team leader will be responsible for ensuring 
effective overall coordination and smooth operationalization of the TA outputs in 
close  collaboration  with  members  of  the  consultant  team  and  the  relevant 
ministries  and  agencies.  Specifically,  the  deputy  team  leader  will  help  (a) 
organize project meetings and consultation workshops, including preparation of 
discussion papers, agendas, correspondence, budget estimates, proceedings, 
and overall logistical support; (b) facilitate consultation with government agencies 
on project products; (c) facilitate the submission and approval process of the 
TA’s outputs; and (d) carry out other project-related tasks upon request. 
(iv)  Review key ongoing regional cooperation and integration initiatives. The 
deputy  team  leader  will  assist  the  team  leader  in  collecting  and  compiling 
necessary information for the review and carrying out consultations on findings 
and finalizing the review. 
(v)  Design a database of key regional cooperation and integration initiatives. 
The deputy team leader will assist the team leader in designing the database, 
take lead in coordinating with government focal points for RCI initiatives to collect 
data and information for the database, and verify data and information for the 
database. 
(vi)  Draft a circular on coordination for the Greater Mekong Subregion program. 
The deputy team leader will carry out necessary study and analysis for drafting 
the circular at the request of the team leader. The deputy team leader will work 
closely with the team leader and other consultants to draft the circular, and 
participate in consultation meetings and help refine it, as necessary. 
(vii)  Organize Greater Mekong Subregion national network meetings. The deputy 
team  leader  will  assist  the  team  leader  in  consulting  GMS  stakeholders  to 
organize  regular  meetings,  and  prepare  agendas,  background  papers,  and 
proceedings. The deputy team leader will review meeting budget estimates for 
approval  of  the  national  GMS  coordinator  and  ADB,  as  well  as  supervise 
necessary logistical arrangements. The deputy team leader will take the lead in 
conducting  surveys  among  network  members  on  the  performance  of  the 
secretariat and scope for improvement. 
(viii)  Capacity building. The specialist work will work closely with the team leader, 
and  help  coordinate  with  agencies  involved  in  the  GMS  program  to  design 
training  programs,  develop  materials,  and  identify  local  resource  persons  as 
appropriate. 
(ix)  Inputs to other activities. The specialist will provide inputs to the various project 
reports, and participate in selected project meetings, as advised by the team 
leader.  
 
5.  Economic  planning  specialist  (national,  10 person-months). The specialist  should 
have a postgraduate degree in economic planning or a related field, extensive knowledge of 
economic integration in Viet Nam, sound work experience in national and regional economic 
planning,  and  at  least  5  years  of  relevant  work  experience,  and  be  familiar  with  the 
interministerial and/or interagency institutional arrangements for public investment planning. 
English  language  competence  is  essential.  The  specialist  will  work  closely  with  other 
international and national consultants to complete tasks assigned, and report to the team leader 
or deputy team leader as appropriate. The assignment includes the following tasks:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  Prepare  and  finalize  the  national  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  investment 
framework and national Greater Mekong Subregion investment plan. The 
expert will lead the preparation and finalization of the NIF and NIP under the 
direct  supervision  of  the  team  leader  and  guidance  of  the  national  GMS 
coordinator,  with  support  from  the  deputy  team  leader  and  other    national 
consultants, as appropriate. A background study may be conducted to review 
and advise on how Viet Nam can become an industrialized nation by 2020 and 
strategically position itself in the global and regional value chain. The NIF and 
NIP will need to be consistent with the Regional GMS Investment Framework, 
national and/or subnational and sector development strategies and plans, and 
other relevant national investment directions. The NIF and NIP should provide 
clear  investment  directions,  selectivity  criteria,  and  financing  plan.  Extensive 
consultation with the GMS program’s stakeholders on the NIF and NIP will be 
required to ensure government ownership and maximize funding possibilities. 
(ii)  Inputs to other activities. The expert will provide inputs to the project’s various 
reports, and participate in selected project meetings, as advised by the team 
leader. 
 
6.  Information technology specialist (national, 6 person-months). The specialist must 
have a university degree in computer science or information and communication technology, 
and skills and experience in developing electronic network systems, databases, and websites 
and their operations. The specialist should be fluent in written and oral English. The specialist 
will work closely with other international and national consultants to complete tasks assigned, 
and report to the team leader or the deputy team leader as appropriate. The assignment 
includes the following tasks: 
(i)  Develop software for a Greater Mekong Subregion program database. The 
expert will develop a program or software that can capture all necessary data 
and information and generate reports for GMS investment planning as guided by 
the  team  leader  and  in  consultation  with  national  stakeholders  of  the  GMS 
program. 
(ii)  Prepare database and e-system operation and maintenance manuals. The 
expert will prepare manuals on the update and/or maintenance of the database 
and other relevant systems. 
(iii)  Training. The expert will train MPI staff on how to use and maintain the database. 
 
7.  Project analysts (2 national analysts, 24 person-months each). The analysts shall have 
at least a bachelor degree, good communication and coordination skills, and experience. They 
will facilitate the implementation of the project by providing administrative and logistical support 
to all other international and national consultants. They will report to the team leader or the 
deputy team leader as appropriate. Their assignment includes the following tasks: 
(i)  assist in undertaking TA-related analytical work; 
(ii)  provide logistical support to all project meetings and training courses; 
(iii)  provide administrative assistance to international and national experts, including 
the preparation of necessary project documents and reports; 
(iv)  facilitate  communication  between  the  National  GMS  Secretariat,  government 
agencies, and the Regional GMS Secretariat; 
(v)  provide assistance in updating the RCI database; 
(vi)  organize and maintain an updated inventory of all files, publications, and other 
documents; and 
(vii)  ensure effective communication and coordination among the ADB project team, 
the MPI, and TA consultants.
